name: anaerobic digestion of manure | biogas | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/15491/documentation

Inventory refers to 1m3 of biogas (which corresponds to 33 kg of farmyard manure). Electricity consumption and emissions represent the average biogas production in a digestion plant based on 34 biogas plants in Switzerland.  Infrastructure expenditures are included.;Reference:;Dinkel & Kägi (2022). Stoffflüsse landwirtschaftliche Biogasproduktion und Ökobilanz

Input of livestock manure (cattle slurry, pig slurry, cattle manure) to incoming storage at the biogas plant.

The treatment includes storage of the substrates at the biogas fermentation plant, anerobic fermentation, as well as the storage of digestate after fermentation. The activity ends with the biogas and digestate being available at the biogas plant. Furthermore, the calorific value of the biogas only accounts for the methane content excluding the H2S presence in it. Glycerine was removed as input in the anaerobic digestion (AD) process. Water content of digestate is 95% in wet weight basis. Finally, the dataset incorporates emissions of CO2, CH4, NH3 and N2O to air due to the storage of the substrates before the AD process as well as from storage of the digestate after the AD process. The storage of the substrate before and after the AD process is assumed to be an under cover system.
category: E:Water supply; sewerage, waste management and remediation activities/38:Waste collection, treatment and disposal activities; materials recovery/382:Waste treatment and disposal/3821:Treatment and disposal of non-hazardous waste

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Conditions refer to anaerobic digestion of manure in Switzerland.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The storage of the substrate and the storage of the digestate (before and after the anaerobic digestion process respectively) are both considered to be closed.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Data refer to Swiss production. Production volumes and uncertainty values have been changed (completeness and geographical index set from 1 to 5).
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: The data for this dataset was generated within a project in 2022 financed by FOGA (Forschungs-, Entwicklungs- und Förderungsfond der schweizerischen Gasindustrie) and Ökostrom Schweiz in order to analyse the material flow analysis of the relevant emissions and the life cycle of Swiss agricultural biogas production based on manure. The data used for modelling were mainly taken from Ökostrom 2021 (Datenzusammenstellung BAFU Kompensationsprojekte 2020) that included data from 34 biogas plants in Switzerland. Emissions, as reported in Ökostrom 2021  are monitored as part of the above mentioned project. Producers are required to provide evidence of emission reduction within the scope of this project in order to participate. Assumptions were validated with biogas experts.

exchanges.description: Gas derived from fermentation of sewage sludge. Sewage gas is well suited as a fuel for co-generation. The obtained heat is sufficient to cover the overall heat consumption of a WWTP, including the heat demand for the fermentation process. Furthermore, sewage gas may be directly burnt for heating purposes. In principle, the generated sewage gas can be upgraded to natural gas quality and then used as a fuel for road vehicles or fed into the natural gas network. In the year 2004 the waste water treatment plant Buholz was equipped with a biogas upgrading plant. The quantity (degradation rate) and quality of the biogas depend on several factors: • composition of the input material (share of dry organic matter) • duration of digestion • temperature inside digestion tank • quality and quantity of co-substrates

exchanges.description: It was assumed that the nitrous oxide emissions between pre-storage and biogas production incl. post-storage are in a similar ratio to the reported methane emissions between pre-storage and biogas production incl. post-storage. This approximation results in around 0.075 g N2O per m3 of biogas.

exchanges.description: Calculated as residual from the mass balance: input manure - outputs and emissions. The density of biogas is assumed to be 1.185628256 kg /m3 of BG in normal conditions of temperature and pressure.

flow.name: Hydrogen sulfide
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Lifespan is taken as being equal to 20 years.In order to take account of the scale effect, the following formula is applied: Ui = U0 x (Ci/C0)^0,7 where Ui is the number of infrastructure units for the reference case i, in “units”; U0 = 1 [unit] is the number of infrastructure units for the reference facility "anaerobic digestion plant, agriculture, with methane recovery"; Ci is the annual biogas production for the reference case i, en m3/year; C0 = 350,000 [m3/year] is the annual biogas production of the reference facility "anaerobic digestion plant, agriculture, with methane recovery". The infrastructure input per kg of substrate is calculated according to the following formula: Ii = Ui x Yi / (20 x Ci) where Ii is the infrastructure input “anaerobic digestion plant, covered, agriculture” for the reference case i, in “units” per kg of substrates; Ui is the number of infrastructure units for the reference case i, in “units”; Yi is the biogas production yield for the reference case i, in m3 of biogas per kg of substrates; Ci is the annual biogas production for the reference case i, in m3/year.

flow.name: anaerobic digestion plant, agriculture, with methane recovery
flow.category: F:Construction/42:Civil engineering/429:Construction of other civil engineering projects/4290:Construction of other civil engineering projects

defaultProvider.name: market for anaerobic digestion plant, agriculture, with methane recovery | anaerobic digestion plant, agriculture, with methane recovery | Cutoff, U
defaultProvider.category: F:Construction/42:Civil engineering/429:Construction of other civil engineering projects/4290:Construction of other civil engineering projects

exchanges.description: Calculated value according to literature: ES(CO2) = (44/12) x C(C) x EF4 x t where ES(CO2) is the carbon dioxide emissions in kg CO2/t of wet substrate; C(C) is the average carbon content of the substrates in kg C/t of wet substrate; EF4 = 7% is the carbon dioxide emission factor; t is the percentage of the time that the substrate is stored at the biogas producer’s (0.1, supposed that the substrates are stored at the biogas producer’s for 10% of the stockage time before digestion). The value includes emissions from the storage of the substrate until its use from the anaerobic digestion process but also emissions from the storage of the digestate until its final use. The CO2 emissions are calculated on the basis of the CH4 emissions, with the hypothesis that 30% of the carbon is emitted in the form of methane and 70% in the form of carbon dioxide (Jungbluth et al., 2007). EDB(CO2) = (44/12) x (0.7/0.3) x (12/16) x EDB(CH4) where EDB(CO2) is the carbon dioxide emissions in kg CO2/t raw digestate; EDB(CH4) is the methane emissions in kg CH4/t raw digestate. Reference: Dauriat A., Gaillard G., Alig M., Scharfy D., Membrez Y., Bachmann N., Steiner R., Charles R., Maltas A., Sinaj S., Analyse de cycle de vie de la production centralisée et décentralisée de biogaz en exploitations agricoles : Rapport final. Hrsg. Station de recherche Agroscope Reckenholz-Tänikon ART & Station de recherche Agroscope Changins-Wädenswil ACW, Zürich et Nyon. Avril, 2012, 1-147 S. Jungbluth, N., Chudacoff, M., Dauriat, A., Dinkel, F., Doka, G., Faist Emmenegger, M., Gnansounou, E., Kljun, N., Schleiss, K., Spielmann, M., Stettler, C., Sutter, J. 2007: Life Cycle Inventories of Bioenergy. ecoinvent report No. 17, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
